review.title: Dirichlet Process with Mixed Random Measures: A Nonparametric Topic Model for Labeled Data
review.abstract: We describe a nonparametric topic model for labeled data. The model uses a mixture of random measures (MRM) as a base distribution of the Dirichlet process (DP) of the HDP framework, so we call it the DP-MRM. To model labeled data, we define a DP distributed random measure for each label, and the resulting model generates an unbounded number of topics for each label. We apply DP-MRM on single-labeled and multi-labeled corpora of documents and compare the performance on label prediction with MedLDA, LDA-SVM, and Labeled-LDA. We further enhance the model by incorporating ddCRP and modeling multi-labeled images for image segmentation and object labeling, comparing the performance with nCuts and rddCRP.

sections.heading: 4. Application with Labeled Documents
sections.text: We measure the performance of DP-MRM with three experiments. First, we compare the identification prediction performance of DP-MRM and LDA-SVM on single-line documents. Then, we compare the identification prediction performance of DP-MRM and L-LDA on multi-line documents. Finally, we compare the identification prediction performance of DP-MRM and L-LDA on heldout data. In the identification prediction experiments, we use a semi-supervised approach: divide the corpus into training and test sets, derive the posterior distribution of the training set with the observed labels (i.e. rjk = 1 only for k-label (j)), and then derive the posterior distribution of the test set with all possible K-labels (i.e. rjk = 1 for all k). In all evaluations, we perform each model ten times with 5,000 iterations, the first 3,000 as burn-in, and then use the samples with 100 gaps from iterations.

sections.heading: 4.1. Single-Labeled Documents
sections.text: DP-MRM is designed to model multi-labeled documents, but it assumes that one label generates multiple themes, so this flexible assumption allows DP-MRM to also be used to model labeled documents. Note that L-LDA for labeled documents would match each word of a document to a single theme, thus modelling the document as a mixture of unique items (i.e. naive bayes). sections.heading: 5. Image Segmentation with ddCRP
sections.text: We describe an enhancement of DP-MRM built into DP-MRM by integrating ddCRP, a non-parametric Bayesian predecessor that takes spatial dependencies into account, illustrating the universality of DP-MRM in that it can replace HDP for data with page information. We test this DP-MRM-ddCRP model on the task of image segmentation for multi-labeled images without manually segmented training data. Image segmentation is often done with manually segmented and labeled data (He et al., 2004; Gould et al., 2009). DP-MRM can also perform supervised image segmentation, but such data is more difficult to obtain, whereas image collections with multiple labels and without segmentation are relatively easy to obtain (e.g. Picasa or Flickr). A recent paper shows a Bayesian model for simultaneous image segmentation and annotation (Du, et al, 2009).

sections.heading: 6. Conclusion
sections.text: The results show that DP-MRM for labeled data produces interpretable topics with greater flexibility than the labeled LDA. A promising extension of our model is the inclusion of prior knowledge of external sources or domain experts in a Bayesian non-parametric topic model. It is outside the scope of this paper, but our model can use different βk for each base distribution, so the structured previous βk of domain experts (Andrzejewski et al., 2009) can be easily integrated into our model.
